The Iraqi Liberation Act of 1998 can be found here.
 
 Please note Section 3 wherein it says:
 
 SEC. 3. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS REGARDING UNITED STATES POLICY TOWARD IRAQ.
 
 It should be the policy of the United States to support efforts to remove the regime headed by Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq and to promote the emergence of a democratic government to replace that regime.
 
 It was not George's idea. It had been planted in his mind by the previous administration, as was the intelligence he used to pull the trigger.

 I think you are making some wild acusations here. We have not "completely abandon" the search for Bin Laden. We have just as many troops in Afganistan on the hunt for OBL now as we did six months into the Afgan invasion. The hunt has not been called off. I personally feel, from the information i have gathered, that Pakistan is the largest deterrient to us catching OBL.
 
 None the less, he is no longer conducting training camps. He is no longer conducting meeting with organizers from all around the globe to atack America. He IS running for his life in the mountains of one of the most remote and isolated areas in this planet. We most certainly weakened the direct influence he had over the terrorists working against us.
 
 I don't mean to sound like I'm advocating calling off the search, because i am not. I know very little about bounty hunting and even less about the Mountain range laying between Afganistan and Pakistan. I do understand that the going is tough on each account and when you combine the two, things get very difficult. 
 
 We don't need the entire US military crawling around in the mountains looking for one man. Nor do we need the entire US military sitting around with baited breath while a few select special forces units do the work at hand. Bush is doing what was voted to be the best solution to fight terror. We now know for sure that Saddam is not a threat. We now have a base in the middle east. We now are working away from the military bases of the cold war and transitioning towards a focal point in the middle east, where the terrorist come from. 
 
 Finally on the oil issue. I ask you to show me one iota of evidence the displays the American consumption of Iraqi oil at a higher rate now than it was prior to the invasion.

Ultimately, the Iraq issue goes back to whether or not you want to blame the president for the bad intelligence he got. 
 
 It's like saying we should fire a police chief for having his officers burst into a house whom he had been told by credible sources held a big cache of automatic weapons, even though they got inside and none were found.
 
 That's the crux of the issue. But it's really a moot point now--the election is over and the majority Americans sided with the police chief . . . um, er, the president.
pnac=ww3

The Iraqi Liberation Act of 1998 can be found here.
 
 Please note Section 3 wherein it says:
 
 SEC. 3. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS REGARDING UNITED STATES POLICY TOWARD IRAQ.
 
 It should be the policy of the United States to support efforts to remove the regime headed by Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq and to promote the emergence of a democratic government to replace that regime.
 
 It was not George's idea. It had been planted in his mind by the previous administration, as was the intelligence he used to pull the trigger.

 It wasn't W's idea, but it really wasn't Clinton's idea either. It was Wolfowitz and Pearle (and some others) who had this policy since 1992. They finally convinced Clinton to call for regime change. Clinton did NOT want that to come about through a war.
 
 The language reads "support efforts" and "promote emergence."
 It does not say "remove by force" or "design new govt."
 
 .
pnac=ww3

Ultimately, the Iraq issue goes back to whether or not you want to blame the president for the bad intelligence he got. 

 Rummy et al. did what's called Data Mining. Where they took a bunch of old unrelated intellegence (and some forged and made up) and strung it together to make it look like something. The CIA was constantly hounding the admin (and DOD) to stop using the language it was using in the sale of the war because it didn't reflect the actual situation on the ground. 
 
That's the crux of the issue. But it's really a moot point now--the election is over and the majority Americans sided with the police chief . . . um, er, the president.

 And what gullible fools they are.
 Eh, but there was no alternative (except to not vote).
